poem:
Title: Absurdity's Gravestone

In the morning's ink, a satire unfurls,
Of refugees, scorn, and the world's cruel twirls.
Devouring tales of white extremism, plague,
Met's fall, NHS's lag.
Gentrified lands, Office homes,
EU's weary domes.
In blood and grit, migrations unfold,
Laughter's armor against the cold.
Serious? Yes. Funny? So they adjudge,
But life's absurdities never hold a grudge.

(60 words)
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Three Burials by Anders Lustgarten review – a madcap satire on the refugee crisis With his debut novel, the British playwright Anders Lustgarten proves Orwell’s dictum that “to be funny, indeed, you have got to be serious”. A loud, populous, madcap satire on Britain’s broken refugee system, the novel takes on white extremism, Covid-19, the decline of the Met and the NHS, gentrification, the Home Office, the EU and migration in all its gritty, blood-soaked details. It". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
